{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2015}} {{Use Irish English|date=March 2015}}
{{Infobox saint |honorific_prefix = [[The Venerable]] |name = Matt Talbot |honorific_suffix = [[Third Order of Saint Francis|O.F.S.]] |image=Talbot.jpg |imagesize=200 |caption=Matt Talbot |titles=Layman |birth_date ={{Birth date|df=yes|1856|5|2}} |birth_place =[[Dublin]], [[Ireland]] |death_date ={{death date and age|df=yes|1925|6|7|1856|5|2}} |death_place =Dublin, Ireland |patronage= {{unbulleted list|People who struggle with alcoholism<ref name=foley/>|Addictions}} | major_works =Piety, charity and mortification of the flesh |resting_place =Our Lady of Lourdes Church, Seán McDermott Street, Dublin | feast_day =19 June |venerated_in= [[Catholic Church]] }}
[[The Venerable]] '''Matt Talbot''', [[Secular Franciscan Order|OFS]] (2 May 1856 – 7 June 1925) was an [[Ireland|Irish]] [[Asceticism|ascetic]] revered by many [[Roman Catholic Church|Catholics]] for his [[piety]], [[charity (virtue)|charity]] and [[mortification of the flesh]].
Talbot was an [[Manual labour|unskilled labourer]]. Though he lived alone for most of his life, Talbot did live with his mother for a time.<ref>[http://www.census.nationalarchives.ie/pages/1911/Dublin/Mountjoy/Rutland_Street__Upper/23750/ 1911 Census of Dublin]</ref> His life would have gone unnoticed were it not for the cords and chains discovered on his body when he died suddenly on a Dublin street in 1925.
Though he has not been formally recognized as a saint, Talbot may be considered a patron of those struggling with alcoholism.<ref name=foley>Leonard Foley OFM, "Venerable Matt Talbot", in ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=_qzIPgAACAAJ Saint of the Day, Lives, Lessons, and Feast]'', (revised by Pat McCloskey OFM), Franciscan Media, {{ISBN|978-0-86716-887-7}}</ref><ref>Don Miller OFM, [https://www.franciscanmedia.org/venerable-matt-talbot/ "Venerable Matt Talbot"], Franciscan Media</ref> He is commemorated on 19 June.<ref name=lapointe>[http://www.conncoll.edu/images/content/Matt_Talbot.pdf LaPointe, Fr. Larry, "Matt Talbot", Connecticut College] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120901090504/http://www.conncoll.edu/images/content/Matt_Talbot.pdf |date=1 September 2012 }}</ref>
==Early life – alcoholism== Talbot was born on 2 May 1856 at 13 Aldborough Court, [[Dublin]], [[Ireland]],<ref name=diocese>[http://www.matttalbot.ie/index.htm "Matt Talbot", Diocese of Dublin]</ref> the second eldest of twelve children of Charles and Elizabeth Talbot, a poor family in the [[North Strand]] area. He was baptised in St. Mary's Pro-Cathedral on 5 May.<ref name=pro>[http://www.procathedral.ie/matt-talbot "Venerable Matt Talbot, 1856 – 1925", [[St. Mary's Pro-Cathedral]], Dublin]</ref> His father and all but the oldest of his brothers were heavy drinkers. In 1868 Matt left school at the age of twelve and went to work in a wine merchant's store. He very soon began "sampling their wares", and was considered a hopeless alcoholic by age thirteen.<ref name=atlanta>[http://www.archatl.com/ministries/disabilities/saints/saint_info.php?0=June+19&feast_date=June+19&1=Venerable+Matt+Talbot&full_name=Venerable+Matt+Talbot&2=Alcoholics&patronage=Alcoholics "Venerable Matt Talbot (Patron of Struggling and Recovering Addicts and Alcoholics)", Archdiocese of Atlanta] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402095740/http://www.archatl.com/ministries/disabilities/saints/saint_info.php?0=June+19&feast_date=June+19&1=Venerable+Matt+Talbot&full_name=Venerable+Matt+Talbot&2=Alcoholics&patronage=Alcoholics |date=2 April 2015 }}</ref> He then went to the Port & Docks Board where he worked in the whiskey stores. He frequented pubs in the city with his brothers and friends, spending most or all of his wages and running up debts.<ref name=mattt>{{cite book|last=Boylan|first= Henry |year=1998|title=A Dictionary of Irish Biography, 3rd Edition|location=Dublin|publisher= Gill and MacMillan|isbn= 0-7171-2945-4|page=419}}</ref> When his wages were spent, he borrowed and scrounged for money. He pawned his clothes and boots to get money for alcohol. On one occasion, he stole a [[fiddle]] from a [[busking|street entertainer]] and sold it to buy drink.<ref name=atlanta/>
=="Taking the pledge"== One evening in 1884 28-year old Talbot, who was penniless and out of credit, waited outside a pub in the hope that somebody would invite him in for a drink. After several friends had passed him without offering to treat him, he went home in disgust and announced to his mother that he was going to "take [[Theobald Mathew (temperance reformer)#Total Abstinence Society|the pledge]]" (renounce drink). He went to [[Holy Cross College (Dublin)|Holy Cross College]], [[Clonliffe]] where he took the pledge for three months. At the end of the three months, he took the pledge for six months, then for life.<ref>[http://www.pioneertotal.ie/pioneer/images/matt.jpg Talbot's pledge certificate from the "Total Abstinence League of Sacred Heart", 4 May 1890]</ref>
Having drunk excessively for 16 years, Talbot maintained sobriety for the following forty years of his life. There is evidence that Matt’s first seven years after taking the pledge were especially difficult.<ref name=foley/> He found strength in prayer, began to attend daily Mass, and read religious books and pamphlets. He repaid all his debts scrupulously. Having searched for the fiddler whose instrument he had stolen, and failed to find him, he gave the money to the church to have [[Mass (liturgy)|Mass]] said for him.
==Working life== Even when his drinking was at its worst, Talbot was a hard worker. When he joined Pembertons, the building contractors, as a [[Brick hod|hod]]-carrier, his work-rate was such that he was put first on the line of hodmen to set the pace. Later, in Martin's timber yard, he took on the meanest and hardest jobs. He was respectful to his bosses but not obsequious, and on occasion stood up for a fellow-worker. On 22 September 1911 Talbot joined the builder's labourers branch of the [[Irish Transport and General Workers Union]]. When the [[Dublin Lockout]] of 1913 led to [[sympathy strike]]s throughout the city, the men of Martin's, including Talbot, came out.<ref name="mattt"/> At first Talbot refused his strike pay, saying that he had not earned it. Later he accepted it but asked that it be shared out among the other strikers. After his death a rumour was put about that he was a strike-breaker in 1913, but all the evidence contradicts this.
==Spirituality== [[File:Matt Talbot.JPG|thumb|200px|Statue of Talbot near Dublin's [[Talbot Memorial Bridge]].]] From being an indifferent Catholic in his drinking days, Talbot became increasingly devout. He lived a life of prayer, fasting, and service, trying to model himself on the sixth century Irish monks.<ref name=atlanta/> He was guided for most of his life by Dr. Michael Hickey, Professor of Philosophy in [[Clonliffe College]]. Under Dr. Hickey's guidance Talbot's reading became wider. He read laboriously Scripture, lives of saints, ''The Confessions of St. Augustine'', and writings of St. Francis de Sales and others. When he found a part difficult to understand, he asked a priest to clarify it.<ref name=atlanta/>
Dr. Hickey also gave him a light chain, (much like a clock chain), to wear as a form of [[penance]].<ref name=atlanta/> He became a [[Third Order]] [[Franciscan]] in 1890 and was a member of several other associations and [[Sodality|sodalities]].<ref name="mattt"/> Talbot was a generous man. Although poor himself, he gave unstintingly to neighbours and fellow workers, to charitable institutions and the church. He ate very little. After his mother's death in 1915 he lived in a small flat with very little furniture. He slept on a plank bed with a piece of timber for a pillow. He rose at 5 a.m. every day so as to attend Mass before work. At work, whenever he had spare time, he found a quiet place to pray. He spent most of every evening on his knees. On Sundays he attended several Masses. He walked quickly, with his head down, so that he appeared to be hurrying from one Mass to another.
==Death and veneration== Talbot was on his way to Mass on Trinity Sunday, 7 June 1925, when he collapsed and died of [[congestive heart failure|heart failure]] on Granby Lane in Dublin. Nobody at the scene was able to identify him. His body was taken to Jervis Street Hospital, where he was undressed, revealing the extent of his austerities. A chain had been wound around his waist, with more chains around an arm and a leg, and cords around the other arm and leg.<ref name="mattt"/> The chains found on his body at death were not some extreme penitential regime but a symbol of his devotion to Mary, Mother of God that he wished to give himself to her totally as a slave.<ref name=bishops>[http://irishbishopsdrugsinitiative.com/?page_id=235 "Matt Talbot", Irish Bishop's Conference]</ref> Talbot's story quickly filtered through the community and there were many spectators when his funeral took place at [[Glasnevin Cemetery]] on 11 June 1925. In 1972 his remains were removed to a tomb in Our Lady of Lourdes Church in Sean McDermott Street, Dublin, in the area where Matt spent his life.<ref name=bishops/>
On 6 November 1931, Archbishop Byrne of Dublin opened a sworn inquiry into the alleged claims of holiness of the former dock worker. The Apostolic Process, the official sworn inquiry at the [[Roman Curia|Vatican]], began in 1947. On 3 October 1975 [[Pope Paul VI]] declared him to be [[Venerable]] Matt Talbot, which is a step on the road to his [[canonisation]], a process which needs evidence of a physical miracle in order to be successful.<ref name="mattt"/> There is a particular devotion to Matt Talbot among some North American Roman Catholics<ref name=bishops/> among those involved in a ministry to achieve or maintain sobriety.
A possible miracle in Kansas, where a healthy child was delivered despite tests showing abnormalities—[[Down syndrome]] or [[cystic fibrosis]]—after his aunt organized a prayer chain asking the intercession of Matt Talbot, is currently under investigation. If shown to be "medically inexplicable", the case may bring Talbot a step closer to sainthood.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gargan|first1=Mags|title=New 'miracle' may put Matt Talbot on road to sainthood|url=http://irishcatholic.ie/article/new-miracle-may-put-matt-talbot-road-sainthood|accessdate=27 February 2015|work=The Irish Catholic|date=1 January 2015}}</ref>
==Legacy== [[File:The Custom House and Matt Talbot Memorial Bridge from City Quay - geograph.org.uk - 1733696.jpg|thumb|left|The Custom House and Matt Talbot Memorial Bridge from City Quay]]
''“Never be too hard on the man who can’t give up drink. It’s as hard to give up the drink as it is to raise the dead to life again. But both are possible and even easy for Our Lord. We have only to depend on him.” – Matt Talbot''<ref name=lapointe/>
As word of Matt Talbot spread he rapidly became an icon for Ireland's temperance movement, the [[Pioneer Total Abstinence Association]]. His story soon became known to the large Irish emigrant communities. Many addiction clinics, youth hostels and statues have been named after him throughout the world from [[Nebraska]] to [[Warsaw]] to [[Sydney]]. One of Dublin's main bridges is also [[Talbot Memorial Bridge|named after him]]. A statue of Talbot was erected at [[Sir John Rogerson's Quay]] in 1988. [[Pope John Paul II]], as a young man, wrote a paper on him.
[[Graham Linehan]] has stated that the character of [[Cigarettes and Alcohol and Rollerblading|Matty Hislop]] in his comedy series ''[[Father Ted]]'' was based on Talbot.<ref>Writer's commentary to 'Cigarettes and Alcohol and Rollerblading', ''Father Ted – The Definitive Collection'', 2 Entertain Video, 2002</ref>
Talbot's remains were removed from Glasnevin Cemetery to Our Lady of Lourdes Church on Seán McDermott Street, Dublin, in 1972. The tomb has a glass panel through which the coffin may be seen.
There is a small plaque in Granby Lane at the site of Matt Talbot's death.
{{clear left}} ==References== {{reflist}}
==Bibliography== *Doherty, Eddie. ''Matt Talbot.'' Madonna House, 2nd edition 2001. {{ISBN|0-921440-67-7}} *Glynn, Sir Joseph A. ''Matt Talbot.'' Dublin: Catholic Truth Society, 1924. Print. *Marynard, Philip. ''Slake a Thirst: The Matt Talbot Way to Sobriety'', Alba House 2000 {{ISBN|0-8189-0843-2}} *Purcell, Mary. ''Matt Talbot and His Times''. Franciscan Pr; Revised edition, 1977 {{ISBN|1-85390-185-7}} *Wallace, Susan Helen. ''Matt Talbot: His Struggle, His Victory over Alcoholism''Pauline Books & Media 1992, {{ISBN|0-8198-4766-6}}
==External links== *[http://www.madonnahouse.org/publications/eddie/matttalbot.htm Matt Talbot], a biography by journalist [[Eddie Doherty]] *[http://www.catholicireland.net/saintoftheday/matt-talbot-the-workers-saint/ Matt Talbot – the workers' saint] at Catholic Ireland * [http://www.clarelibrary.ie/eolas/claremuseum/news_events/presidential_acknowledgement_of_matt_talbot_community.htm Irish Presidential Acknowledgement of the Matt Talbot Community] at Clare County Library *[http://www.savior.org/saints/talbot.htm Venerable Matthew Talbot] at Savior.org *[https://web.archive.org/web/20051205115747/http://www.catholic-forum.com/Saints/saintm8j.htm Patron Saints Index: Venerable Matt Talbot] at Catholic Community Forum *[http://www.catholic.org/saints/saint.php?saint_id=430 Venerable Matt Talbot] at Catholic Online

{{Other uses}} {{Use mdy dates|date=February 2015}} {{Infobox referendum | name = Measure B - 2012 | title = County of Los Angeles Safer Sex In the Adult Film Industry Act | yes = 1617866 | no = 1222681 | invalid = | total = 2840547 | electorate = 4593621 }} '''Measure B''', also known as the '''''County of Los Angeles Safer Sex In the Adult Film Industry Act''','' is the law that requires the use of [[condom]]s in all [[Sexual intercourse|vaginal]] and [[Anal sex|anal]] sex scenes in [[pornography]] productions filmed in [[Los Angeles County]], California. The measure also requires porn production companies to obtain a health permit prior to production and to post the permit and a notice to performers regarding condom use during production. All individuals involved will also be required to pay $1,600 every 2 years.<ref name=LWVCA121217>{{cite web |title=Measure B: Safer Sex In the Adult Film Industry Act - County of Los Angeles |url=http://www.smartvoter.org/2012/11/06/ca/la/meas/B/ |publisher=League of Women Voters of California Education Fund |accessdate=October 18, 2012}}</ref>
==History== In 2009 similar legislation was introduced at the [[California|State]] level. Citing an HIV positive test for a performer in May of that year, the [[Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors]] sought to find a sponsor for a bill to mandate condom use in adult films. They had originally approved a resolution to seek legislation in October 2008, and made it part of their official state legislative agenda in December.<ref name=StateCondom>{{cite web|last=Staff|title=L.A. pushes for condoms in porn legislation, but state lawmakers balk|url=http://capitolweekly.net/l-a-pushes-for-condoms-in-porn-legislation-but-state-lawmakers-balk/|publisher=Capitol Weekly|accessdate=March 11, 2014}}</ref> The primary testing center at the time was the [[Adult Industry Medical Health Care Foundation]] (AIM). Prior to this, in 2004, there were several related cases of HIV positive tests reported. Of the twenty-two reported cases roughly half were among men who work in gay films, while the rest were both men and women working in heterosexual productions.<ref name=StateCondom/>
Measure B was voted on November 6, 2012 and passed with 55.9% of the vote.<ref name=LAT121107-1>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=November 7, 2012 |title=Condom requirement for porn filming approved by voters |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2012/11/condom-requirement-for-porn-filming-approved-by-voters.html |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |location= |accessdate=September 23, 2014}}</ref><ref name=LAT121107-2>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date=November 7, 2012 |title=Porn industry trade group vows to fight condom requirement |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2012/11/porn-industry-trade-group-plans-to-fight-condom-decision.html |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |accessdate=November 8, 2012}}</ref>
==Campaign==
===Support=== In 2012 proponents gathered 372,000 voter signatures through a citizens' initiative in Los Angeles County to put Measure B on the 2012 ballot.<ref>{{cite conference | url = https://apha.confex.com/apha/141am/webprogram/Paper282652.html | title = Successful advocacy for condoms in adult films: from idea to ballot, how did we do it? | first = Mark | last = McGrath | date = November 5, 2013 | conference = 141st Annual Meeting and Expo November 2–6, 2013, Boston, Massachusetts | conference-url = https://apha.confex.com/apha/141am/webprogram/start.html | publisher = [[American Public Health Association]] | location = Boston, Massachusetts | id = Paper no. 282652 | access-date = 9 November 2015}}</ref> Supporters of Measure B said it would stop the spread of [[STDs in the porn industry]] and protect tax dollars.<ref name=YesOnB>{{cite web |title=Vote Yes On B |url=http://www.yesonb.info/ |publisher= [[Los Angeles County Medical Association]] |accessdate=October 18, 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121029100926/http://www.yesonb.info/ |archivedate=October 29, 2012}}</ref>
Supporters included porn performer [[Aurora Snow]],<ref>{{cite news |last=Snow |first=Aurora | author-link = Aurora Snow |date=October 18, 2012 |title=Condoms in Porn: One Adult Star Says Yes to Measure B |url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2012/10/18/condoms-in-porn-one-adult-star-says-yes-to-measure-b.html | work= [[The Daily Beast]] | publisher = [[IAC (company)|IAC]] |accessdate=October 19, 2012}}</ref> [[Jenna Jameson]],<ref name=YesOnB/> [[Shelley Lubben#Pink Cross Foundation|Pink Cross Foundation]],<ref>{{cite news|last=Montague|first=Candace Y.A.|title=Los Angeles Council Votes in Favor of Condoms for Porn Actors|url=http://www.thebody.com/content/65424/los-angeles-council-votes-in-favor-of-condoms-for-.html|accessdate=January 20, 2013 | work = [[James D. Marks|TheBody.com]] | publisher = [[James D. Marks|Body Health Resources Corporation]] |date=January 12, 2012}}</ref> and Michael Weinstein, president of the [[AIDS Healthcare Foundation]]. Weinstein claims that according to the Los Angeles County Public Health Department, "thousands of performers have been infected with thousands of STDs over the last few years."<ref name=WeinsteinHuffBlog>{{cite web|last=Weinstein|first=Michael|title=Condoms in Porn Are Important|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/michael-weinstein/condom-use-porn_b_1313436.html | work = [[The Huffington Post]] | publisher = [[AOL]] |accessdate=February 18, 2014}}</ref>
===Opposition=== The [[MindGeek#No on Government Waste Committee|No On Government Waste Committee]] opposed Measure B claiming it would waste tax-payer money and drive the porn industry out of the state.<ref>{{cite web |title=No On Government Waste |url=http://www.noongovernmentwaste.com/ |accessdate=October 18, 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121022052248/http://www.noongovernmentwaste.com/ |archivedate=October 22, 2012 | work = noongovernmentwaste.com | publisher = [[MindGeek#No on Government Waste Committee|No on Government Waste Committee]]}}</ref> It said that it was supported in its opposition by the Los Angeles County Federation of [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] Women, Los Angeles County Republican and [[Libertarian Party (United States)|Libertarian]] Parties, and the [[Log Cabin Republicans]] of Los Angeles.<ref>{{cite press release |last= |first= |date= |title=Log Cabin Republicans of Los Angeles announce opposition to Measure B, Says No on Government Waste Committee |url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/log-cabin-republicans-los-angeles-150000501.html |location= |publisher=[[Yahoo! Finance]] |agency=[[MindGeek#No on Government Waste Committee|No on Government Waste Committee]] |accessdate=September 23, 2014}}</ref>
The ''[[Los Angeles Times]]''<ref>{{cite news|title=No on Measure B|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/opinion/editorials/la-ed-end-measure-b-20121018,0,1623510.story|accessdate=November 11, 2012 |work= [[Los Angeles Times]] | publisher = [[Tribune Publishing]] |date=October 18, 2012}}</ref> and ''[[Los Angeles Daily News]]''<ref>{{cite news | title = Endorsement: No on B -- Measure to force condoms in porn films is redundant and could harm an important local industry | url = http://www.dailynews.com/opinions/ci_21795793/endorsement-no-b-measure-force-condoms-porn-films|accessdate=November 11, 2012|work= [[Los Angeles Daily News]] | publisher = [[Digital First Media]] |date=October 17, 2012}}</ref> both editorialized in opposition to Measure B.
Opponents include porn performers [[Kayden Kross]], Ava Addams, [[Ron Jeremy]], [[Tera Patrick]], [[Tanya Tate]],<ref name="PressCon"/> [[Priya Anjali Rai]], [[Jessica Drake]], [[Steven St. Croix]], [[Danny Wylde]], and [[James Deen]].<ref name=DailyMail8November2012>{{cite news|last=Shergold|first=Adam|title=California votes to mandate condoms in porn industry|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2229232/Measure-B-California-votes-mandate-condoms-LA-porn-industry-amid-fears-industry-leave-state.html?ITO=1490&ns_mchannel=rss&ns_campaign=1490 |accessdate=November 8, 2012| work = [[Daily Mail]] | publisher = [[Daily Mail and General Trust]] |date=November 8, 2012}}</ref>
Tate was quoted in a [[San Fernando Valley Business Journal]] article to the effect that she would want whomever she decided to have sex with "to get tested until I felt comfortable to sleep with them without a condom," adding that [[AIDS Healthcare Foundation]] president Michael Weinstein (who the article was about), "should be spending money on treating [AIDS] and educating regular people about how to protect themselves instead of going after a small community that is aware of the risks."<ref name=PressCon>{{cite web|last=Kernes|first=Mark|title='No on Government Waste' Committee holds 1st press conference |url=http://business.avn.com/articles/legal/No-on-Government-Waste-Committee-Holds-1st-Press-Conference-488400.html|work=[[AVN (magazine)|Adult Video News]] | publisher = [[AVN Media Network]] |accessdate=February 11, 2014}}</ref>{{irrelevant citation|date=November 2015|reason=Citation bears no relation to quote.}}
Pornographic actress [[Nina Hartley]], who has a [[Bachelor's degree|degree]] in [[nursing]], said: "Shooting scenes with condoms are noticeably more uncomfortable." She said they cause friction burns vaginally and anally, that they slip off and rip, and that they get stuck inside. "They aren't built to withstand our shoots," she said. [[Stoya]], another female performer in adult films, said, "If you condense the amount of time we were actually having sex, it probably added up to almost four to five hours."<ref name=HuffCondom>{{cite web |last=Williams |first=Mitchell |title=How a straight adult performer convinced me that condoms are useless in porn |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/mitchell-williams/how-a-straight-adult-performer-convinced-me-that-condoms-are-useless-in-porn_b_2165066.html | work = [[The Huffington Post]] | publisher= [[AOL]] |accessdate=February 18, 2014}}</ref>
==After effects==
===Technical opposition=== In January 2014, [[Falcon Entertainment]] countered the ban after its passing by using [[post-production]] editing to remove the condoms from footage in its film ''California Dreamin' 1''; the edits were intentional, as the film was intended to reflect the "carefree and spontaneous" style of the 1970s and 80s.<ref name=Opam140120>{{cite web |last=Opam |first=Kwame |date=January 20, 2014 |title=Porn studio digitally removes condoms from release to provide 'pre-condom fantasy' |url=https://www.theverge.com/2014/1/20/5327506/porn-studio-digitally-removes-condoms-from-releases-to-provide-pre |work=The Verge |accessdate=January 20, 2014}}</ref>
The financial and technical viability of this was challenged by an expert in videography in 2009.<ref name=2009NonViable>{{cite web|last=Kernes|first=Mark|title='Removal' Of Condoms From XXX Scenes Not A Real Option Another argument in favor of mandatory condoms in adult movies bites the dust|url=http://business.avn.com/articles/video/Removal-Of-Condoms-From-XXX-Scenes-Not-A-Real-Option-347654.html|publisher=Adult Video News|accessdate=March 11, 2014}}</ref> [[Axel Braun]], in his experience as a director and the owner of the post-production company Level 5 Post, reiterated this in 2014.<ref name=BraunVSMsrB>{{cite web|last=Kernes|first=Mark|title=Axel Braun: Removing Condoms From Sex Scenes Still Unrealistic|url=http://business.avn.com/articles/video/Axel-Braun-Removing-Condoms-From-Sex-Scenes-Still-Unrealistic-551840.html|publisher=Adult Video News|accessdate=March 11, 2014}}</ref>
===Commentary=== In her first column for the [[OC Weekly]], performer [[Tasha Reign]] reiterated Hartley and Stoya's comments regarding the impracticality of imposing condoms on the industry. Reign said, "Want to know a dirty secret that Measure B proponents, who say what they did was in the interest of us supposedly helpless performers, never brought up? After hours of sex with no breaks, attempting to endure the friction of the condom in your vagina or anus is...impossible. And to do this daily amounts to an occupational work hazard. Of course, due to the lack of respect towards the adult business and blatant disregard from society regarding the sexual comfort or even opinions of female performers, none of this mattered. No one asked us."<ref>{{cite news|last=Reign|first=Tasha|authorlink=Tasha Reign|title=Tasha Tells All...On LA County's Measure B Condom Law|url=http://blogs.ocweekly.com/navelgazing/2013/04/tasha_tells_measure_b.php|accessdate=February 18, 2014|newspaper=[[OC Weekly]]|date=April 8, 2013 <!-- at 7:30 AM --> }}</ref>
In November 2012, [[Vivid Entertainment]] CEO [[Steven Hirsch]] and pornographic actors Dahlia Sky, [[Penny Pax]], Veruca James, [[Steven St. Croix]] and Michael Vegas appeared in a video titled "Thank You From the Porn Industry" for [[Funny or Die]]. The video lampoons Measure B and requiring the use of [[condoms]] in all sex scenes filmed in [[Los Angeles County]].<ref>{{cite web|url= http://business.avn.com/articles/technology/Funny-or-Die-Enlists-Vivid-to-Lampoon-Measure-B-495172.html|title= Funny or Die Enlists Vivid to Lampoon Measure B|accessdate= December 2, 2013|author= Mark Kernes|date= November 20, 2012|publisher= ''[[AVN (magazine)|AVN]]''}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.xbiz.com/news/156761|title= Vivid's Hirsch, Adult Stars Spoof Measure B in Funny or Die Vid|accessdate= December 2, 2013|author= John Sanford|date= November 20, 2012|publisher= ''[[XBIZ]]''}}</ref>
===Industry exodus from Los Angeles County=== ;2013 Industry and agency officials say there has been a shift in where porn is made, and estimated the potential economic impact at US$6 billion.<ref name=2014LVSun/> In November 2013, [[Diane Duke]], executive director of industry trade group [[Free Speech Coalition]], said, "Fewer people are shooting (adult film) in L.A. County, and some have moved to other areas around California or other states...".<ref name=1YR>{{cite news |last=Abram |first=Susan |date=November 4, 2013 |title=One year later, condoms-in-porn law reshapes industry in L.A. County |url=http://www.dailynews.com/social-affairs/20131104/one-year-later-condoms-in-porn-law-reshapes-industry-in-la-county |newspaper=Los Angeles Daily News |accessdate=February 18, 2014}}</ref> Two months later, ''[[The Verge]]'' reported, "in the midst of rampant piracy on top of Measure B, many studios have relocated to [[Las Vegas]], where filmmaking is cheaper and regulations are more lax."<ref name=Opam140120/> Then in September 2014, Robert Lang, director of Brookings Mountain West (a collaboration of [[UNLV]] and the [[Brookings Institution]] to study issues facing the [[Intermountain West]] region), was quoted as saying, "Some big part of it will stay (in LA) and production companies will continue to be based there, so it's not accurate to say that all of that $6 billion translates to Southern Nevada. But what it also gives to Las Vegas is that it's building technical capacity that undergirds non-pornographic production and media. It adds some competitive advantage in scale to Los Angeles."<ref name=2014LVSun/>
In the months after the measure passed, production companies began seeking shooting locations outside of Los Angeles County.<ref>{{cite web|author=Associated Press|last=|title=Camarillo, Calif. Porn Film Moratorium Passed After Deluge Of Film Permit Requests|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/03/28/camarillo-porn-film-moratorium_n_2973642.html|publisher=Huffington Post|accessdate=February 18, 2014}}</ref> In the [[Ventura County]] city of [[Camarillo, CA]], the [[city council]] passed a forty-five-day [[Moratorium (law)|moratorium]] on the issuance of [[film permits]], including special-event and conditional-use permits, for porn productions due to the increased number of applications.<ref name=VCSPornPermit>{{cite news|last=Letzer|first=Jennifer|title=Camarillo council places moratorium on porn movie production|url=http://www.vcstar.com/news/2013/mar/28/council-places-moratorium-on-pornographic-film/|accessdate=February 18, 2014|newspaper=Ventura County Star|date=March 28, 2013 <!--9:14 p.m.-->}}</ref>
A year after the passing of the measure, it was reported that prior to Measure B typically up to 500 permits would be applied for in Los Angeles County with [[FilmL.A.]], the nonprofit that processes permits for motion picture, television and commercial productions. In 2013, applications were received for twenty-four permits.<ref name=LADN1YR>{{cite news|last=Abram|first=Susan|title=Porn industry to gather in Los Angeles for annual conference|url=http://www.dailynews.com/arts-and-entertainment/20140120/porn-industry-to-gather-in-los-angeles-for-annual-conference|accessdate=February 18, 2014|newspaper=Los Angeles Daily News|date=January 20, 2014 <!--9:27 PM PST-->}}</ref> A spokesman with the county's Department of Public Health said that eleven health permits were requested by adult-film studios.
;2014 One of the industry's largest producers, [[Vivid Entertainment]], has gone outside Los Angeles County since the law took effect. Co-founder [[Steven Hirsch]] said, "We will not be shooting in L.A. under the current situation, which is too bad," "There's a uniqueness to L.A. you can't find anywhere such as backdrops. It's also impacted us financially because shooting outside the county can become more expensive." Some production moved to [[Las Vegas]] citing a more favorable environment.<ref name=Aftermath>{{cite news|last=Dreier|first=Hanna|title=Condom law aftermath: Porn production booms in Las Vegas after move from San Fernando Valley|url=http://www.dailynews.com/arts-and-entertainment/20140117/condom-law-aftermath-porn-production-booms-in-las-vegas-after-move-from-san-fernando-valley|accessdate=February 18, 2014|newspaper=Los Angeles Daily News|date=January 17, 2014 <!--9:25 AM PST-->}}</ref> [[Clark County, Nevada|Clark County]], where Las Vegas is located, does not require health permits and gives out location licenses for a nominal fee; filming permits in Los Angeles County can cost hundreds of dollars.<ref name=Aftermath/>
In September 2014, the ''[[Las Vegas Sun]]'' featured an article about the adult industry's possible relocation from Southern California to Las Vegas.<ref name=2014LVSun>{{cite news|last1=Domanick|first1=Andrea|title=Porn Wars: Is Las Vegas the new Silicone Valley?|url=http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2014/sep/21/porn-las-vegas-condom-kink-illegal-film-aids-healt/|accessdate=September 24, 2014|publisher=Las Vegas Sun newspaper|date=September 21, 2014}}</ref> According to commentary by ''AVN'' magazine's political analyst Mark Kernes, the author of the ''Sun'' article, Andrea Domanick, "manages to make a few good points—and snags some quotes from [[Kink.com]] CEO Peter Acworth".<ref name=2014AVN-LVSun>{{cite web|last1=Kernes|first1=Mark|title=New Article in Las Vegas Sun Catches Up With Porn's Reality|url=http://business.avn.com/articles/legal/New-Article-in-Las-Vegas-Sun-Catches-Up-With-Porn-s-Reality-573647.html|website=AVN.com|publisher=Adult Video News|accessdate=September 24, 2014}}</ref> In the article Acworth is quoted as saying, "Vegas is looking more and more attractive as time goes by... I think that a lot of companies are doing what we're doing. They're setting up satellite offices and getting their feet wet with Vegas as a potential place to shoot. The move is happening, but quietly. They don't want a target on their back."<ref name=2014LVSun/> Acworth had announced several weeks earlier that he was shopping for office/production space in Las Vegas.<ref name=2014AVN-LVSun/> The article also mentions the ease of production relative to California by stating that Nevada requires film permits only for specific locations and conditions. It states, "Shooting on private property, frequently the choice of porn producers, requires no permit or notification, and the state has no explicit regulations about condom use."<ref name=2014LVSun/> The article also quotes a technician with knowledge of the mainstream film industry in Southern California and Nevada. Jim Reid of JR Lighting, one of Nevada's largest production rental companies stated, "A lot of people I know in the mainstream industry started out in the adult industry in California. It's a very good training ground."<ref name=2014LVSun/>
In December, after the ruling of the [[Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals]] regarding the measure, it was announced that applications for permits for pornographic productions has reduced by 95%.<ref name=20149thNo/>
===State legislation - AB1576=== On January 30, 2014 California Assemblyperson [[Isadore Hall]] ([[California Democratic Party|D]] – [[Compton, California|Compton]], 64th District) introduced Assembly Bill 1576.<ref name=AB1576Text>{{cite web|last1=Staff|title=AB1576|url=http://www.leginfo.ca.gov/pub/13-14/bill/asm/ab_1551-1600/ab_1576_bill_20140130_introduced.html|website=legalinfo.ca.gov|accessdate=June 18, 2014}}</ref> Like its failed predecessor, AB640 in 2013 (also introduced by Hall),<ref name=AB640-2013>{{cite web|last1=Staff|title=Aseembly Bill 640 (2013)|url=http://openstates.org/ca/bills/20132014/AB640/|website=openstates.org|accessdate=June 24, 2014}}</ref> the bill is a statewide version of Measure B that affects Los Angeles County only and makes it a criminal offense to violate its provisions.<ref name=2014AB1576Tracking>{{cite web|last1=Staff|title=AB1576|url=http://www.legtrack.com/bill.html?bill=201320140AB1576|website=www.legtrack.com|accessdate=June 18, 2014}}</ref> The bill also imposes a controversial government mandate on testing, forcing producers to disclose performers' [[Sexually transmitted infection|STI]] test details to the [[California Department of Industrial Relations|Department of Industrial Relations]].<ref name=Stop1576>{{cite web|last1=Staff|title=Stop1576|url=http://www.ab1576.org/|website=www.ab1576.org|accessdate=June 18, 2014}}</ref> As of June 2014 the bill has passed through the Labor and Employment (04/01/14), ARTS, ENTERTAINMENT, SPORTS, TOURISM, AND INTERNET MEDIA (04/28/14), APPROPRIATIONS (05/20/14), and ASSEMBLY FLOOR ANALYSIS (5/22/14) committees.<ref name=2014AB1576Tracking/>
In June five adult actresses met with Hall's district director, Heather Hutt, at the legislator's office on Artesia Boulevard in Compton and presented 650 signed petitions asking that the Assemblyman withdraw his "condoms in porn" bill. At the meeting with Hutt were adult film actresses [[Nina Hartley]], Alex Chance and [[Anikka Albrite]], along with industry newcomers Mia Li and Charli Piper and Michael Stabile, a publicist who has been working with [[Free Speech Coalition]] (FSC) and [[Kink.com]] on the issue. The group expressed their disappointment with the bill and the fact that it had been created with no input from adult industry representatives.<ref name=2014AVN1576Petition>{{cite web|last1=Kernes|first1=Mark|title=Adult Actresses Deliver Petitions to Isadore Hall Office-UPDATED|url=http://business.avn.com/articles/legal/Adult-Actresses-Deliver-Petitions-to-Isadore-Hall-Office-UPDATED-564968.html|website=AVN.com|publisher=Adult Video News|accessdate=June 24, 2014}}</ref> In an interview with [[AVN magazine]], Chance stated the following,
<blockquote>We told [Hutt] we have our own self-regulation..." "We told her we wanted to have our voices heard. They'd had no performer input on this. About condoms and chafing and micro-tears, it didn't seem like she really knew all the details of that. She compared it to a dentist being forced to wear gloves, and maybe it's a little uncomfortable. She didn't realize why we have to have sex from 45 minutes to an hour, sometimes longer, and why that was necessary. She didn't know that the dangers of it, like if the condom breaks, and that we could get more STI's with the micro-tears, and just the condoms in general: Swelling, yeast infections, things of that nature—she just had no idea." "She also didn't know about the doctors with the FSC that help make the decisions," Chance added. "It's not just a couple of people in a building making decisions for the whole industry. They don't even make decisions on the moratoriums; a doctor does, and she had no idea about that and what the testing protocols—how the doctors work with them to make the most safe tests available; she had no idea.<ref name=2014AVN1576Petition/></blockquote>
In the thirty-five minute meeting Director Hutt mentioned that in the 2012 election the most votes cast in any district in favor of passage of Measure B came from Hall's district. Actress Nina Hartley countered that although Measure B and AB 1576 were written by policy makers at AIDS Healthcare Foundation, the AHF had yet to open a clinic in Compton which has one of the highest HIV infection rates in [[Los Angeles County]].<ref name=2014AVN1576Petition/>
===Proposition 60===
In 2016, the AIDS Healthcare Foundation backed [[California Proposition 60 (2016)|Proposition 60]], which would have enacted a condom mandate similar to Measure B statewide. Proposition 60 was defeated at the polls.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Chappell|first=Bill|url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2016/11/09/501405749/condom-mandate-for-porn-industry-falls-short-in-california|title=Condom Mandate For Porn Industry Falls Short In California|newspaper=NPR.org|date=November 9, 2016|access-date=November 15, 2016}}</ref>
==Legal appeal==
===2013=== In January 2013, Universal City-based [[Vivid Entertainment]] filed a lawsuit against the Los Angeles County health department saying that the measure violated actors' rights to free speech and expression. In August 2013, [[U.S. District Judge]] [[Dean Pregerson]] delivered a mixed ruling to the adult film industry saying that while making actors wear condoms during porn shoots does not violate the [[First Amendment]], enforcing such a law raises constitutional questions, and denied the adult film industry's motion for a preliminary injunction.<ref name=Lawsuit1>{{cite news|last=Abram|first=Susan|title=LA's condoms in porn law gets a mixed legal ruling|url=http://www.dailynews.com/general-news/20130817/las-condoms-in-porn-law-gets-a-mixed-legal-ruling|accessdate=February 11, 2014|newspaper=Los Angeles Daily News|date=August 17, 2013 <!--11:11 AM PDT-->}}</ref>
Judge Pregerson agreed that some of the provisions and language of measure were too vague and did not sufficiently explain condom use when other sex acts were being filmed. He also questioned the manner of inspections to be conducted and agreed with the industry that their rights could be violated. Pregerson wrote, "Given that adult filming could occur almost anywhere, Measure B would seem to authorize a health officer to enter and search any part of a private home in the middle of the night, because he suspects violations are occurring. This is unconstitutional because it is akin to a general warrant...".<ref name=Lawsuit1/>
Both sides considered the judgment a victory. Vivid Entertainment founder and co-chairman [[Steven Hirsch]] said in a statement that he is pleased with the decision regarding the enforcement questions, but plans to appeal the part of the ruling that upholds the measure. He stated, "We won most everything we sought to be determined unconstitutional with Measure B. We are, however, disappointed the Court found it necessary to rewrite a portion of the measure in order to salvage a small portion of the measure and refused, at this time, to accept the adult industry's own regulations by imposing an unfunded mandate upon the county by AHF." AIDS Healthcare Foundation president Michael Weinstein stated, "Today's ruling that requiring condoms in porn is constitutional is just a tremendous, tremendous victory, one that will go a long way to safeguard the health and safety of those adult performers working in the industry." Vivid filed an appeal.<ref name=1YR/>
===2014=== In March 2014, the appeal of Judge Pregerson's ruling was argued before the [[Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals]], with a three-judge panel asking questions to both the appellants and the appellee, which was the AIDS Healthcare Foundation (AHF) rather than the lawsuit's official defendant, Los Angeles County.<ref name=March2014Appeal>{{cite web|last=Staff|title=Ninth Circuit Hears Measure B Appeal|url=http://business.avn.com/articles/legal/Ninth-Circuit-Hears-Measure-B-Appeal-551133.html|publisher=Adult Video News|accessdate=March 5, 2014}}</ref> The panel was headed by Ninth Circuit Chief Justice [[Alex Kozinski]], Circuit judge [[Susan P. Graber]], a Clinton appointee, and Judge [[Jack Zouhary]] of the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Ohio, a George W. Bush appointee.<ref name=March2014Appeal/>
On December 15, the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals affirmed a lower court's order denying a motion to overturn the Measure.<ref>Vivid Entertainment v. Fielding, No. 13-56445 (9th Cir., Dec. 15, 2014), available at http://legalmasters.net/wp-content/uploads/2015/03/9th-Circuit-Affirm-Denial-of-Injunction-of-LA-Safer-Sex-Initiative-13-56445.pdf</ref> In the ruling, it was stated "that the district court did not abuse its discretion in holding that the invalid portions of Measure B (allowing for modification, suspension, and revocation of permits; authorizing administrative searches; and allowing discretion in setting fees) were severable".<ref name=20149thNo>{{cite web|last1=Pardon|first1=Rhett|title=Vivid Loses Appeal Over Measure B|url=http://www.xbiz.com/news/188984|website=XBIZ.com|publisher=XBIZ|accessdate=December 16, 2014}}</ref> The effect of which is that court upheld the portions of the Measure which were not struck down by U.S. District Court Judge Pregerson. The court also took the position that "the condom mandate ... has only a [[de minimis]] (negligible) effect on expression." According to [[AVN (magazine)|AVN]] magazine legal analyst [[Mark Kernes]] this position ignores "the fact that historically, every company that has adopted a mandatory condom policy has experienced a drop in sales, which translates to a decreased ability to have its message seen by the public."<ref name=2014AVNanalysis>{{cite web|last1=Kernes|first1=Mark|title=Ninth Circuit Panel Upholds Measure B—At Least Until Trial Three-judge panel claims it has jurisdiction to review the case despite AHF's lack of standing|url=http://business.avn.com/articles/legal/Ninth-Circuit-Panel-Upholds-Measure-B-At-Least-Until-Trial-582719.html|website=AVN.com|publisher=Adult Video News|accessdate=December 16, 2014}}</ref>
Regarding the ruling, [[Diane Duke]], CEO of the [[Free Speech Coalition]], stated,<ref name=2014FSC>{{cite web|title=FSC: 'Measure B Decision will Hurt Performers'|url=http://business.avn.com/articles/legal/FSC-Measure-B-Decision-will-Hurt-Performers-582729.html|website=AVN.com|publisher=Adult Video News|accessdate=December 16, 2014}}</ref>
<blockquote>While this intermediate decision allows that condoms may be mandated, it doesn't mean they should be. We have spent the last two years fighting for the rights of adult performers to make their own decisions about their bodies, and against the stigma against adult film performers embodied in the statute. Rather than protect adult performers, a condom mandate pushes a legal industry underground where workers are less safe. This is terrible policy that has been defeated in other legislative venues.</blockquote>
AHF president Michael Weinstein stated,<ref name=2014AHF>{{cite web|last1=Kenslea|first1=Ged|title=U.S. Appeals Court Upholds Condoms In Porn Mandate|url=http://www.aidshealth.org/#/u-s-appeals-court-upholds-condoms-in-porn-mandate/|website=AIDS Health|accessdate=December 16, 2014}}</ref>
<blockquote>Today's ruling is a total vindication of AHF's position. We call on Los Angeles County for full enforcement of this law now. As the lower court said, they need to set fees based on actual cost. The porn industry has considered every option but following the law. Now it's time to do what fifty-seven percent of Los Angeles County voters have asked of the industry—and what the courts have upheld as constitutional.</blockquote>
He further stated that he hoped the adult entertainment industry will continue to appeal, taking the case to the U.S. Supreme Court, for a final and definitive ruling.<ref name=20149thNo/>
==See also== * [[Adult Industry Medical Health Care Foundation]] * [[HIV/AIDS in the pornographic film industry]] * [[Performer Availability Screening Services]] * [[Pornography in the United States]]
== Further reading == * {{cite journal | last = Webber | first = Valerie | title = Public health versus performer privates: Measure B's failure to fix subjects | journal = [[Porn Studies]] | volume = 2 | issue = 4 | pages = 299–313 | publisher = [[Taylor and Francis]] | doi = 10.1080/23268743.2015.1053094 | date = October 2015 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/23268743.2015.1053094 | ref = | postscript = .}}

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=October 2013}}
'''Medical education in Iraq''' is based on the 6-year [[United Kingdom|British]] [[curriculum]] and is carried out in [[English language|English]]. Medical education is free, and all required textbooks are provided free to students. [[Postgraduate education|Postgraduate]] residency training is required for both [[Iraqi people|Iraqi]] and [[Arab]] board certification in each specialty. Before the [[Gulf War]], the [[Politics of Iraq|government]] funded subspecialty training abroad.
Academic [[physician]]s in [[Iraq]], most of whom are specialists, are expected to publish their research in [[peer review]]ed journals to be eligible for promotion to the highest levels. After [[United Nations]] sanctions were imposed in 1990, the delivery of [[Europe]]an and [[United Nations|American]] [[medical journal]]s to Iraq abruptly stopped.<ref>{{cite web | last = J Richards | first = Leila |author2=Stephen N Wall | title = Iraqi medical education under the intellectual embargo | work = THE LANCET, Volume 355, Number 9209 25 | date =March 2000 | url = http://www.converge.org.nz/pma/irmedi.htm | accessdate = Jan 2009 }} </ref>
==Facilities== There are 20 colleges of [[medicine]] in Iraq, seven colleges of [[nursing]], 10 colleges of [[dentistry]] and 8 colleges of [[pharmacy]] in addition to 6 technical colleges and 20 colleges of sciences which take the responsibility for supporting [[health care]] services and delivery.<ref>June 2007 - Volume 5, Issue 4, Middle east Journal of Family Medicine, Quality and Accreditation in Health Professions Education in Iraq - Accreditation in Health Professions Education, Dr. Thamer Kadum Yousif Al Hilfy, http://www.mejfm.com/volume-5_issue-4/towards_quality.htm{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Iraqi doctors== US officials report that an estimated 8,000 Iraqi [[Physician|doctor]]s stopped practicing medicine from 2003 to 2008 because doctors became targets for [[murder]] and [[kidnapping]]. US health officials say Iraq probably needs about 100,000 doctors to meet the needs of its population, but has only 15,000 now.<ref>"Iraqi doctors training in US", By KEVIN FREKING, Associated Press Writer Sunday, November 30, 2008, http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/n/a/2008/11/30/national/w052924S16.DTL</ref>
In 1994, hoping to prevent doctors from [[emigration|emigrating]], the [[Iraqi government]] encouraged private medical practices. Four years later it allowed [[hospital]]s to charge some fees. The government also encouraged organizations including the [[Red Cross]] and the [[Red Crescent]] to build PHCs and help support hospitals.<ref name=corpwatch>health care system in Iraq, High-Tech Healthcare in Iraq, Minus the Healthcare by Pratap Chatterjee, Special to CorpWatch January 8th, 2007, http://warprofiteers.com/article.php?id=14290 {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090328132837/http://www.warprofiteers.com/article.php?id=14290 |date=2009-03-28 }}</ref>
==See also== *[[List of medical colleges in Iraq]]
==References== {{reflist|2}} *[https://books.google.com/books?id=uqQwIHpqpfgC&pg=PA201&dq=saddam+medical+city&lr=&num=20&as_brr=1&as_pt=ALLTYPES#PPA201,M1 World Directory of Medical Schoolspage201]
[[Category:Health education in Iraq]]

{{Infobox lake | name = Lower Kama Reservoir, Nizhnekamsk Reservoir | image = Nishnekamsk reservoir Naberezhnye Chelny.JPG | caption = Nishnekamsk reservoir near [[Naberezhnye Chelny]]. | image_bathymetry = | caption_bathymetry = | location = | coords = {{coord|55|53|N|52|45|E|region:RU_source:frwiki_type:waterbody|display=inline,title}} | type = [[Hydroelectricity|Hydroelectric]] [[reservoir]] | inflow = [[Kama River|Kama]], [[Belaya River (Kama)|Belaya]], [[Ik River|Ik]], [[Izh River|Izh]], [[Syun River|Syun]], [[Menzelya River]]s | outflow = [[Kama River|Kama]] | catchment = | basin_countries = [[Russia]] | length = {{convert|200|km|abbr=on}} | width = | area = {{convert|1,084|km2|abbr=on}} | depth = | max-depth = | volume = {{convert|2.8|km3|e6acre.ft|abbr=on}} | residence_time = | shore = | elevation = 63,3 (68 planned) | frozen = | islands = | cities = [[Naberezhnye Chelny]]
[[Mendeleyevsk]]
[[Menzelinsk]]
[[Sarapul]]
[[Neftekamsk]]
[[Kambarka]]
[[Agidel]] | reference = }} '''Lower Kama Reservoir''' or '''Nizhnekamsk Reservoir''' ({{lang-ru|Нижнекамское водоранилище}}, {{lang-tt|Түбән Кама сусаклагычы}}) is the lowest reservoir from the [[Kama River]] hydroelectric cascade. It is situated in [[Tatarstan]], [[Udmurtia]], [[Bashkortostan]] and [[Perm Krai]], [[Russian Federation]]. The reservoir was filled in 1978-81 up to 62 m above sea level after the construction of dam of the [[Lower Kama Hydroelectric Station]]. The water level in reservoir depends on the upper reservoirs regime ([[Kama Reservoir]] and [[Votkinsk Reservoir]]). The Lower Kama Reservoir has a surface area of 1,084 km² and a volume of 2.8 billion cubic meters. Its length along Kama is 185 km and 157 km along [[Belaya River (Kama)|Belaya]]. The reservoir also used for water supply, irrigation and fishing.{{TES|}} The planned level of the reservoir is 68 m above sea level. Tatarstan government announced plans to reach the full planned power of the electric station.[http://archive.rferl.org/reports/tb-daily-report/ Parliament Gives Up On Reviving Kama Alany Nuclear Power Station Project] However, ecological movement inside of Tatarstan opposes these plans, as the reservoir will flood [[Kulyagash]] wetland and other lands in that case.[http://archive.rferl.org/reports/tb-daily-report/2005/10/0-031005.asp Nuclear Project Sparks Criticism] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{Commons category-inline|Nizhnekamsk Reservoir}} {{Kama river}} [[Category:Reservoirs in Russia]] [[Category:Reservoirs in Tatarstan]] [[Category:Reservoirs in Bashkortostan]] [[Category:Reservoirs in Perm Krai]] [[Category:Reservoirs in Udmurtia]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Tatarstan]]

revision.text:
__NOTOC__ '''Nutrition Education''' is any combination of educational strategies, accompanied by environmental supports, designed to facilitate voluntary adoption of food choices and other food- and nutrition-related behaviors conducive to health and well-being. Nutrition education is delivered through multiple venues and involves activities at the individual, community, and policy levels.<ref>Nutrition education: Linking research, theory and practice. Jones & Bartlett, 2007</ref>{{page number needed|date=July 2017}}
The work of nutrition educators takes place in colleges, universities and schools, government agencies, [[Cooperative extension service|cooperative extension]], communications and public relations firms, the food industry, voluntary and service organizations and with other reliable places of nutrition and health education information. Nutrition education is a mechanism to enhance awareness,{{citation needed|date=July 2017}} as a means to self-efficacy, surrounding the trigger of healthy behaviors<ref>Ronda G, Van Assema P, Brug J. Stages of change, psychological factors and awareness of physical activity levels in The Netherlands. Health Promot Int. 2001;16(4):305-314</ref>
Examples of government agencies that incorporate nutrition education into their programs, include: * [[Let's Move]], launched by First Lady [[Michelle Obama]] in February 2010, through the [http://www.letsmove.gov/healthierschoolfood.php Healthier US School Challenge]; * USDA [[Food and Nutrition Service]], which provides nutrition education materials to children and adults of all ages and nutrition education to [[Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program]] (SNAP) participants and applicants; * [[National Institute of Food and Agriculture|USDA National Institute of Food and Agriculture]] through the [http://www.nifa.usda.gov/qlinks/extension.html cooperative extension program]; and * [[MyPyramid|MyPyramid.gov]], through the [http://www.mypyramid.gov/tips_resources/tentips.html Ten Tips Nutrition Education Series].
Examples of technological innovations by private enterprise include: *''' [[fooya]]''' a [[mHealth|mobile health]] [[Mobile app|App]] by [[FriendsLearn]] is designed for children, to improve their awareness about healthy eating, while reinforcing the role of physical activity on health. It has been shown to have positive health outcomes through underlying methods of [[Neuropsychology]], [[Health Coaching]] and [[Cognitive Behavior Therapy]], as observed during randomized and controlled clinical trials conducted by researchers at the [[Baylor College of Medicine]] Children's Nutrition Research Center<ref>{{cite web|url=http://medicinex.stanford.edu/conf/submission/view/343|author=[[Stanford]] MedicineX|date=6 July 2015|title=Neuropsychology based Behavior Design through Mobile Health Gaming|publisher=[[Stanford University School of Medicine]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://2014.obesityweek.com/wp/uploads/2014/10/TOS-Posters.pdf|publisher=[[The Obesity Society]]|author=Dr Craig Johnston, Dr Jennette Moreno, et al [[Baylor College of Medicine]]|title=A Nutrition Education Mobile Game Impacts Snack Selection in Middle School Students|date=2 November 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304060846/http://2014.obesityweek.com/wp/uploads/2014/10/TOS-Posters.pdf|archivedate=4 March 2016|df=}}</ref>
== Additional Publications == 1.The [http://www.jneb.org/ Journal for Nutrition Education and Behavior], the official journal of the [http://www.sneb.org/ Society for Nutrition Education and Behavior], documents and disseminates original research, emerging issues and practices relevant to nutrition education and behavior worldwide.
== See also == <!-- Please keep entries in alphabetical order & add a short description [[WP:SEEALSO]] --> * [[5 A Day]] * [[Food and Nutrition Service]] * [[Food guide pyramid]] * [[Food Balance Wheel]] * [[Fruits & Veggies – More Matters]] * [[Healthy diet]] * [[Healthy eating pyramid]] *[[History of USDA nutrition guides]] * [[Human nutrition]] * [[Let's Move]] * [[MyPlate]] * [[MyPyramid]] *[[Nutrition Education and Training Program]] * [[Society for Nutrition Education]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.sneb.org Society for Nutrition and Behavior]
