page.title: Women's reproductive health in the United States

revision.text:
'''Women’s reproductive health in the United States''' refers to the set of physical, mental, and social issues related to the health of [[women in the United States]]. It includes the rights of women in the United States to adequate sexual health, available contraception methods, and treatment for sexually transmitted diseases. The prevalence of women’s health issues in American culture is inspired by [[second-wave feminism]] in the United States.<ref name="Overview of Women's Health since 1960's">{{cite journal|last1=Rosser|first1=Sue V.|title=Overview of Women's Health in the U.S. Since the Mid-1960's|journal=History and Technology|date=December 2002|volume=18|issue=4|pages=355–369|doi=10.1080/0734151022000023802|url=http://www.swetswise.com/link/access%5Fdb?issn=0734-1512|deadurl=y|accessdate=25 October 2014}}</ref> As a result of this movement, women of the United States began to question the largely male-dominated health care system and demanded a right to information on issues regarding their physiology and anatomy.<ref name="Overview of Women's Health since 1960's"/> The U.S. government has made significant strides to propose solutions, like creating the [[Women’s Health Initiative]] through the Office of Research on Women’s Health in 1991.<ref name="Overview of Women's Health since 1960's"/>
==Issues==
===Sexual health=== The Department of Health and Human Services has developed a definition for sexual health in the United States based on the [[World Health Organization]]’s definition of sexual health.<ref name="WHO Defining sexual health">{{cite journal|last1=World Health Organization|title=Defining sexual health: report of a technical consultation on sexual health|date=January 2002|pages=28–31|accessdate=25 October 2014|url=http://www.who.int/reproductivehealth/publications/sexual_health/defining_sexual_health.pdf}}</ref>
“Sexual health is a state of well-being in relation to sexuality across the life span that involves physical, emotional, mental, social and spiritual dimensions. Sexual health is an intrinsic element of human health and is based on positive, equitable, and respectful approach to sexuality, relationships, and reproduction, that is free of coercion, fear, discrimination, stigma, shame, and violence.<ref name="Dept. of Health and Human Services">{{cite journal|last1=Department of Health and Human Services|title=CDC/HRSA Advisory Committee on HIV, Viral Hepatitis, and STD Prevention and Treatment|date=May 2012|url=https://www.cdc.gov/maso/facm/pdfs/CHACHSPT/20120508_CHAC.pdf|accessdate=25 October 2014}}</ref>"
The United States government recognizes that gender is a factor which plays a significant role in sexual health.<ref name="Dept. of Health and Human Services"/>
===Contraception=== The U.S. Department of Health and Human Services has identified national reproductive health goals including reducing the level of unintended pregnancy.<ref name="Inapprop Use of CHC">{{cite journal|last1=Yu|first1=Jingbo|author2=Henry Hu|title=Inappropriate Use of Combined Hormonal Contraceptives for Birth Control Among Women of Reproductive Age in the United States|journal=Journal of Women's Health|date=2013|volume=22|issue=7|pages=595–603|doi=10.1089/jwh.2012.3955}}</ref> Out of all the pregnancies reported in the United States, half are unplanned.<ref name="Dept. of Health and Human Services" /> Of the 62 million women in the U.S. who are able to have children, seven out of ten of these women are sexually active but do not want to become pregnant.<ref name="Inapprop Use of CHC">{{cite journal|last1=Yu|first1=Jingbo|author2=Henry Hu|title=Inappropriate Use of Combined Hormonal Contraceptives for Birth Control Among Women of Reproductive Age in the United States|journal=Journal of Women's Health|date=2013|volume=22|issue=7|pages=595–603|doi=10.1089/jwh.2012.3955}}</ref> [[Contraception]] is a major issue of women’s reproductive health. 86% of sexually active women practice some form of contraception and 30% of these women use a hormonal form of contraception.<ref name="Inapprop Use of CHC">{{cite journal|last1=Yu|first1=Jingbo|author2=Henry Hu|title=Inappropriate Use of Combined Hormonal Contraceptives for Birth Control Among Women of Reproductive Age in the United States|journal=Journal of Women's Health|date=2013|volume=22|issue=7|pages=595–603|doi=10.1089/jwh.2012.3955}}</ref> Women in the U.S. have more freedoms in deciding their use of contraceptives among other global nations, comparatively.
The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) have significant pull over the decision-making process women must make when choosing different types of contraception. Women of the U.S. still rely on their healthcare providers for the majority of information they receive about contraceptive use. In order to help healthcare providers provide appropriate family planning care, the CDC published the US Medical Elibility Criteria for Contraceptive Use,2010.<ref name="Inapprop Use of CHC">{{cite journal|last1=Yu|first1=Jingbo|author2=Henry Hu|title=Inappropriate Use of Combined Hormonal Contraceptives for Birth Control Among Women of Reproductive Age in the United States|journal=Journal of Women's Health|date=2013|volume=22|issue=7|pages=595–603|doi=10.1089/jwh.2012.3955}}</ref> The CDC lists methods of [[birth control]] under two categories: reversible and permanent.
====Reversible methods of birth control<ref name="CDC Contraception">{{cite web|last1=Division of Reproductive Health, National Center for Chronic Disease Prevention and Health Promotion|title=Contraception|url=https://www.cdc.gov/reproductivehealth/UnintendedPregnancy/Contraception.htm|website=www.cdc.gov|accessdate=25 October 2014}}</ref>====
*Copper T intrauterine device (IUD) or levonorgestrel intrauterine system (LNG IUD) *Hormonal methods **Implant **Injection **Combined oral contraceptives **Progestin-only pill **Patch **Hormonal vaginal contraceptive ring **Emergency contraception *Barrier methods **Diaphragm or cervical cap **Male condom **Female condom **Spermicides *Fertility awareness-based methods **Family planning **Fertility Awareness **Abstinence
====Permanent methods of birth control<ref name="CDC Contraception">{{cite web|last1=Division of Reproductive Health, National Center for Chronic Disease Prevention and Health Promotion|title=Contraception|url=https://www.cdc.gov/reproductivehealth/UnintendedPregnancy/Contraception.htm|website=www.cdc.gov|accessdate=25 October 2014}}</ref>====
*Female sterilization *Transcervical sterilization
====Hormonal contraception==== [[Hormonal contraception]] is the most popular method of contraception among women in the United States. Women under the age of thirty more commonly use hormonal oral contraception as their preferred method. Hormonal contraceptives can be almost 100% effective when used perfectly,<ref name="Urban Family Medicine IUC">{{cite journal|last1=Rubin|first1=Susan E.|author2=Ilana Winrob|title=Urban Female Family Medicine Patients' Perception About Intrauterine Contraception|journal=Journal of Women's Health|date=2010|volume=19|issue=4|pages=735–740|doi=10.1089/jwh.2009.1549|publisher=Mary Ann Liebert, Inc.}}</ref> but in most cases it is used imperfectly. Oral hormonal contraceptives have an 8% failure rate.<ref name="Urban Family Medicine IUC">{{cite journal|last1=Rubin|first1=Susan E.|author2=Ilana Winrob|title=Urban Female Family Medicine Patients' Perception About Intrauterine Contraception|journal=Journal of Women's Health|date=2010|volume=19|issue=4|pages=735–740|doi=10.1089/jwh.2009.1549|publisher=Mary Ann Liebert, Inc.}}</ref> The popularity of oral hormonal contraceptives among women changes over the course of a year with 32% of women deciding to discontinue use of an oral hormonal contraceptive after one year of typical use.<ref name="Urban Family Medicine IUC">{{cite journal|last1=Rubin|first1=Susan E.|author2=Ilana Winrob|title=Urban Female Family Medicine Patients' Perception About Intrauterine Contraception|journal=Journal of Women's Health|date=2010|volume=19|issue=4|pages=735–740|doi=10.1089/jwh.2009.1549|publisher=Mary Ann Liebert, Inc.}}</ref>
====Intrauterine contraception==== A large stigma exists among women on the topic of using an [[intrauterine device]] (IUD) as a form of contraception. The two types of IUDs that exist for current contraceptive use are Copper T 380A and levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine system or Mirena. IUDs are underutilized by women in the United States with only 2% of women using IUD as an effective contraception.<ref name="Urban Family Medicine IUC">{{cite journal|last1=Rubin|first1=Susan E.|author2=Ilana Winrob|title=Urban Female Family Medicine Patients' Perception About Intrauterine Contraception|journal=Journal of Women's Health|date=2010|volume=19|issue=4|pages=735–740|doi=10.1089/jwh.2009.1549|publisher=Mary Ann Liebert, Inc.}}</ref> The effectiveness of a contraceptive is described in terms of perfect use and typical use. An IUD is different than most forms of contraception, as it is 100% effective in both cases of use.<ref name="Urban Family Medicine IUC">{{cite journal|last1=Rubin|first1=Susan E.|author2=Ilana Winrob|title=Urban Female Family Medicine Patients' Perception About Intrauterine Contraception|journal=Journal of Women's Health|date=2010|volume=19|issue=4|pages=735–740|doi=10.1089/jwh.2009.1549|publisher=Mary Ann Liebert, Inc.}}</ref> It is not possible to use IUDs improperly or inconsistently because they must be inserted inside of the uterus. Women in the United States have many fears about the use of IUDs, making them the less popular form of contraception.<ref name="Urban Family Medicine IUC">{{cite journal|last1=Rubin|first1=Susan E.|author2=Ilana Winrob|title=Urban Female Family Medicine Patients' Perception About Intrauterine Contraception|journal=Journal of Women's Health|date=2010|volume=19|issue=4|pages=735–740|doi=10.1089/jwh.2009.1549|publisher=Mary Ann Liebert, Inc.}}</ref> For many women in the U.S., IUDs are only an option when other traditional contraception methods have been used (hormonal birth control, barrier methods, etc.) or when a women has already had children.<ref name="Urban Family Medicine IUC">{{cite journal|last1=Rubin|first1=Susan E.|author2=Ilana Winrob|title=Urban Female Family Medicine Patients' Perception About Intrauterine Contraception|journal=Journal of Women's Health|date=2010|volume=19|issue=4|pages=735–740|doi=10.1089/jwh.2009.1549|publisher=Mary Ann Liebert, Inc.}}</ref> The fear surrounding use of an IUD stems from a lack of proper education on all available contraception options available to women in the U.S.. Women have cited being afraid of the quality of the device itself, placing the device inside their bodies voluntarily, and the time required to hold the device in place.<ref name="Urban Family Medicine IUC">{{cite journal|last1=Rubin|first1=Susan E.|author2=Ilana Winrob|title=Urban Female Family Medicine Patients' Perception About Intrauterine Contraception|journal=Journal of Women's Health|date=2010|volume=19|issue=4|pages=735–740|doi=10.1089/jwh.2009.1549|publisher=Mary Ann Liebert, Inc.}}</ref> There is a lack of knowledge about female anatomy and pregnancy prevention, even among women of the United States.
===Sexually Transmitted Diseases=== A health objective of the United States government through The United States Public Health Service is to reduce the number of cases of [[sexually transmitted diseases]] from the 1980s to today.<ref name="Testing for STDs">{{cite journal|last1=Mosher|first1=William D.|author2=Sevgi O. Aral|title=Testing for sexually transmitted diseases among women of reproductive age: United States, 1988|journal=Family Planning Perspectives|date=October 1991|volume=23|issue=5|pages=216–221|doi=10.2307/2135756}}</ref> The Centers for Disease Control is responsible for many studies on the topic of STDs as well as the effect of STDs on women and girls.<ref name="Something we'd not talk about">{{cite journal|last1=Friedman|first1=Allison L.|title="Something We'd Rather Not Talk About": Findings from CDC Exploratory Research on Sexually Transmitted Disease Communication with Girls and Women|journal=Journal of Women's Health|date=2010|volume=19|issue=10|pages=1823–1831|doi=10.1089/jwh.2010.1961}}</ref> STDs are defined by the CDC as “infections you can get from having sex with someone who has an infection”.<ref name="CDC Women's Reproductive Health" /> There are more than twenty types of identifiable STDs caused by bacteria, parasites, or viruses.<ref name="CDC Women's Reproductive Health">{{cite web|last1=Division of Reproductive Health, National Center for Chronic Disease Prevention and Health Promotion|title=Women's Reproductive Health|url=https://www.cdc.gov/reproductivehealth/WomensRH/index.htm|website=www.cdc.gov|accessdate=25 October 2014}}</ref> Within one year in the United States there are an estimated 12 million cases of sexually transmitted diseases that occur. Of those 12 million cases there are 1.5 million cases of gonorrhea, 500,000 cases of genital herpes, and 110,000 cases of syphilis.<ref name="Testing for STDs"/> Both women and men in the United States are affected by the STD epidemic. However, women have a stronger negative health reaction to some STDs than men. The negative health effects of STDs for women can include [[pelvic inflammatory disease]] (PIV), ectopic pregnancy, chronic pelvic pain, infertility, fetal and perinatal infections, complications to pregnancy, fetal loss, cervical cancer, and increased risk of tubal pregnancy, intrauterine growth retardation and preterm delivery.<ref name="Testing for STDs"/><ref name="Something we'd not talk about">{{cite journal|last1=Friedman|first1=Allison L.|title="Something We'd Rather Not Talk About": Findings from CDC Exploratory Research on Sexually Transmitted Disease Communication with Girls and Women|journal=Journal of Women's Health|date=2010|volume=19|issue=10|pages=1823–1831|doi=10.1089/jwh.2010.1961}}</ref> Women in the U.S. are less likely to seek out treatment for STDs for a variety of reasons. Some STDs appear asymptomatic in women<ref name="Testing for STDs"/> therefore women are less likely to seek out treatment for STDs than men. Like most health topics, there is a gap that exists in understanding the pathology of diseases in women versus men. Women receive less than adequate information about the prevalence of STDs as well as the symptoms of STDs.
As with contraception in the U.S., a stigma exists which prevents women from learning about all possible STDs and their treatment. A study by the Journal of Women’s Health identified STDs as a topic women would rather not talk about.<ref name="Something we'd not talk about">{{cite journal|last1=Friedman|first1=Allison L.|title="Something We'd Rather Not Talk About": Findings from CDC Exploratory Research on Sexually Transmitted Disease Communication with Girls and Women|journal=Journal of Women's Health|date=2010|volume=19|issue=10|pages=1823–1831|doi=10.1089/jwh.2010.1961}}</ref> Women, with their partners, do not commonly discuss STDs as well.<ref name="Something we'd not talk about">{{cite journal|last1=Friedman|first1=Allison L.|title="Something We'd Rather Not Talk About": Findings from CDC Exploratory Research on Sexually Transmitted Disease Communication with Girls and Women|journal=Journal of Women's Health|date=2010|volume=19|issue=10|pages=1823–1831|doi=10.1089/jwh.2010.1961}}</ref> The stigma surrounding STDs in the U.S. prevents women from discussing the topic even among healthcare provides, close friends, partners, and family. Younger women do not understand the risk that STDs can pose to them. For example, [[Chlamydia infection|Chlamydia]] is one of the most common STDs affecting women and men in the United States. Women do not follow the recommendation that people should be screened for Chlamydia at least once per year.<ref name="Something we'd not talk about">{{cite journal|last1=Friedman|first1=Allison L.|title="Something We'd Rather Not Talk About": Findings from CDC Exploratory Research on Sexually Transmitted Disease Communication with Girls and Women|journal=Journal of Women's Health|date=2010|volume=19|issue=10|pages=1823–1831|doi=10.1089/jwh.2010.1961}}</ref> Most women do not even know any information about Chlamydia as an STD besides the fact that it is curable.<ref name="Something we'd not talk about">{{cite journal|last1=Friedman|first1=Allison L.|title="Something We'd Rather Not Talk About": Findings from CDC Exploratory Research on Sexually Transmitted Disease Communication with Girls and Women|journal=Journal of Women's Health|date=2010|volume=19|issue=10|pages=1823–1831|doi=10.1089/jwh.2010.1961}}</ref>
STD screening is most effective for identifying STDs in women, but is commonly underutilized by women in the U.S. Healthcare access and access to family planning clinics increases the probability that women will seek out and utilize STD screening.<ref name="Testing for STDs"/> Screening is a form of testing healthy versus symptomatic people against traditional symptoms of STDs to determine STD prevalence. The Planned Parenthood Federation of America has available clinics across the United States for the purpose of screening for STDs as well as other family planning services. [[Planned Parenthood]] suggests that sexually active women screen for STDs at least annually.<ref name="Testing for STDs"/> A study by the Journal for Women’s Health identified a need for a knowledge campaign on STD screening targeting sexually active young women.<ref name="Something we'd not talk about">{{cite journal|last1=Friedman|first1=Allison L.|title="Something We'd Rather Not Talk About": Findings from CDC Exploratory Research on Sexually Transmitted Disease Communication with Girls and Women|journal=Journal of Women's Health|date=2010|volume=19|issue=10|pages=1823–1831|doi=10.1089/jwh.2010.1961}}</ref>

{{multiple issues| {{primary sources|date=March 2012}} {{advertisement|date=April 2016}} }} {{Infobox organization | name = World Association of Eye Hospitals | image = Logo of the World Association of Eye Hospitals.jpg | established = June 3, 2007 | type = [[Health care]] organization | services = [[Ophthalmology]] | headquarters = [[World]]wide | key_people = J.C.A. Sol ([[Chairman]], as of 2012) | website = {{URL|http://www.waeh.org/}} }}
The '''World Association of Eye Hospitals''' (WAEH) is a worldwide network of leading hospitals, Founded in 2007 in [[Rotterdam]], It promotes [[ophthalmology]] practice through social outreach and information on eye care and [[health administration]]
== Objectives == * to promote, to encourage and to develop ophthalmology by developing and disseminating information on planning, operating [[hospital services]], funding and quality * to promote and to maintain contacts with ophthalmic organizations ] worldwide * to promote and to maintain contacts with major worldwide institutions - [[eye hospital]]s - [[eye center]]s * to be engaged in other activities to promote [[ophthalmology]] in the broadest sense
== Activities == * Exchange information and knowledge * Exchange of [[personnel]] to enhance [[international network]] and exchange of best practice. * Stimulate international [scientific cooperation between members
== Members ==
=== Full members === * [http://www.thoneh.com/ Tun Hussein On National Eye Hospital] ( Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia) * [http://www.rveeh.vic.gov.au/ Royal Victorian Eye and Ear Hospital] ( Melbourne, Australia)<ref>[http://www.health.vic.gov.au/healthvictoria/jun10/focus.htm International focus on Eye and Ear - RVEEH] Accessed on December 21st, 2011</ref> * The Department of Ophthalmology of the [http://www.uzleuven.be/en University Hospital Leuven] (Belgium) * [[Singapore National Eye Centre]] (Singapore)<ref>[http://www.snec.com.sg/about/international-affiliations/Pages/home.aspx INTERNATIONAL ACTIVITIES - Singapore National Eye Centre] Accessed March 3, 2012</ref> * [[Moorfields Eye Hospital]] (London, UK) * [http://www.rutnin.com/ Rutnin Eye Hospital] ( Bangkok, Thailand) * [http://www.sankterik.se/ St. Erik Eye Hospital] (Stockholm, Sweden) * The [http://www.oogziekenhuis.nl/ Rotterdam Eye Hospital] (Rotterdam, The Netherlands) * [http://www.rveeh.ie/ The Royal Victoria Eye and Ear Hospital] - (Dublin, Ireland) * [http://www.jec-online.com/ Jakarta Eye Center], (Jakarta, Indonesia) * [http://www.tmuec.com/tmuec/english/Eabout.jsp Tianjin Medical University Eye Centre], (China) * [http://www.sesiahs.health.nsw.gov.au/sydhosp/ Sydney Eye Hospital], (Sydney, Australia) * [http://www.kimeye.com/eng_main/eng_sub_07.asp Kim's Eye Hospital - Korea] * [http://www.adityajyoteyehospital.org/ Aditya Jyot Eye Hospital – Maharashtra – India]
=== Associate members === * Himalayan Eye Center - Nepal * Mechi Eye Center - Nepal * [http://cteyehospital.com/ Cao Thang Eye Hospital] - Vietnam * [http://www.institutodecienciasoftalmologicas.com/ Institute of Ophthalmic Science - Angeles Lomas Hospital] - Mexico * [[Aravind Eye Hospital]], India * [http://www.azp.sr/oogheelkunde Suriname Eye Center, Suriname] * [http://www.ctgeyeinfirmary.info/ Chittagong Eye Infirmary and training Complex – Chittagong – Bangladesh]
== Admission criteria (full member) == The admission criteria include specialising at an eye [[hospital]] or [[eye]] department, with at least 5 sub-specialities ( [[cornea]], [[glaucoma]], [[cataract]], [[retina]], [[pediatric]], [[Neuro-ophthalmology|neuro]], [[oculoplastics]] and [[uveitis]]), having carried out at least 5000 [[Surgery|operations]], possessing research and resident training programs, provision of community services, primary care and emergency service, and meeting international and nation quality standards.
